reviewText: This movie doesn't have any particular target audience with it's story.  There are so many entertaining parts that it is definately a must have for anyone who likes a good laugh.  We sometimes try to seperate ourselves for animals that we forget how much their behaviors are like ours.  There are so many scenes in this movie that I was laughin out loud.  Although even though I saw this movie several years ago I still remember several scenes.  So I really do believe it does more than make you laugh, it educates you on how precious the circle of life is.  If you have any remote interest in wild animals or just like to laugh this movie is for you.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A wonderful movie! This is clearly not a biology documentary but, as some books and movies about animals do, it probably does more for nature preservation, than some scientifically accurate movies.Watch this if you like reading Gerald Durrel's books about animals - the authors voice has the same quiet and kind humor as do Durrel's books.Jamie Uys made a rare kind of a movie - he makes you like every single creature that you see. By the end of the movie you migth not know a whole lot about their behavioural or food habits (though there is some information of that kind  too) but you will be in love with every single living thing there is. Before that movie I only knew two people who could do that - Durrel and Herriot. Durrel could spend a couple of hilarious pages describing a toad so at the end you will feel you admired and loved that toad as much as he did. Jamie Uys definitely shares that ability.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you love nature,you'll also find it's beauty here,in this little sort of documentary.There're so many beauties around us that we don't notice(even in our own self).while nothing is perfect,the nature IS.Nature has always won!!In many aspects or appearances(as we know),men are mammalians,but are 'universal' animals coz men can talk,can think and can create things out of materials and ideas.Animals follow their instincts.In few words,animals think without talking,but sometimes men talk without thinking.Learn to accept and appreciate animals,like we may learn to accept and appreciate ourselves as living creatures.Do read my review regarding the crocodiles.I recommended this piece,it's astonishing!!!
summary: The beauty you see around you is your beauty

reviewText: This is recommended for all ages. We were giggling before the opening credits were through, and rolling with laughter by the end.  The film is done documentary style, but the narrator and crew really put their all into giving the viewer a unique experience.  I had seen this as a child in the early 1980's and remembered parts of it through the years (who could forget giraffes tipsy from the marula tree fruit, or a baboon with a hangover?), but could never find a copy, until now.  Enjoy!

reviewText: I saw this years ago. It's quite entertaining. The same sense of humor in "Gods..." is evident - it's a gentle, compassionate humor. I particularly loved the segment where animals of all types are gathered at a feast of fallen and fermented fruit. Some of the takes may be contrived, but it's not a serious documentary. It's entertainment with a message. Enjoy it as such, and you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: Beautiful Movie"Beautiful People" is an action packed wild life adventure story of animal life in Southern Africa. This is a fantastic and captivating story where all the actors are all natural, with the exception being a Bushman who is in any case so close to nature that he is part of it.Among some of my unforgettable moments include the honey barger and the bird. These two work as a team; the bird finding the beehive and the honey barger takes the honey, eats his share and leaves the bird its fair share. One also sees a fish that keeps its young in its mouth for protection and occasionally lets out to play. It was amusing to see all sorts of animals getting drunk after eating the potent amarula fruit. It was also a joy to see how the animals and birds celebrate the coming of the rainy season.I have been to all the countries in Southern Africa where this film was taken namely Namibia, Botswana and Zimbabwe. The rough beauty of the Namib Desert is unique and has to be seen. The natural beauty of the landscape in Zimbabwe and Botswana are breathtaking.The movie was exceptionally well made with stunning photography, excellent music and good and fun actors which are well worth watching for the family. Those who like animals and nature will love this movie.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is not your average animal film. It is done with great humor and as well as being educational and sometimes irreverent, beyond that it is a 'musical appreciation' film. Magnificent music that to brings to life the uplift and down draft of the animal and insect kingdom  living in and on some of the worlds most inhabitable deserts. The music sweeps you along in the daily and nightly efforts of these creatures as they go about life as nature intended. I greatly respect the restraint of the director as he bypasses the usual  animal eat animal fare, leaving that knowledge to your imagination. There are wonderful stories within the film that leave you wishing for more. This is a family must.
summary: For animal lovers with a sence of humor!

reviewText: This is one of the most entertaining documentaries of African wildlife that I have ever seen. The photography is wonderful, and the narration style is uplifting. Most of the animal interactions are lighthearted and comical, but there are some very sad and poignant moments as well. I strongly recommend this film for adults and children alike. I have watched it several times over the years, and never tire of it!

reviewText: First off -  a caveat: this film was produced in 1974 and has not been re-mastered. That said, this is one of my all time favorite documentaries. This is sheer whimsy with a dose of really good fun. This is a prequel to "The Gods Must Be Crazy" and "The Gods Must Be Crazy II." I highly recommend all of these films. The photography is superb. The "story" lines are hugely entertaining and informative. The narration is without equal on entertainment value. Thanks to the producers, directors, photographers and the narrator. I will enjoy this treat time after time.

reviewText: A superb mix of humor and sadess, blended effortlessly into something you'd almost expect National Geographic to put together. It's something the whole family can watch (a few slightly rougher scenes, though, if the children are really sensitive), yet will keep adults entertained too.Was the one scene man-induced? If it was, how do you get elephants, warthogs and baboons to drink the huge quantities of alcoholic beverages necessary to get them that stinko? I think maybe the marula fruit is perhaps more powerful than one self-proclaimed authority site informs us
summary: Just enjoy the film, because it's highly enjoyable

reviewText: This is an amazing look at the beauty of sub Saharan Africa.  It includes animals, plants, and indigenous people.The setting includes the Namib Desert, the Kalahari, and the Okavango Swamp.  The harsh realities and the incredible beauty of nature are both highlighted.  The producer has done a superb job of combining the realities of Africa with a lot of entertainment.  It includes insects, birds, and reptiles along with a wealth of mammals.Some of the fun includes elephants and other animals who have gotten intoxicated while consuming fermenting marula berries, acrobatic baboons, and an impala taunting a lioness.  There are many other great parts too.This is an absolute 'must watch' for anyone who loves Africa and/or wild game.  It will provide lots of enjoyment for just about everyone else as well.
summary: A Fun Frolic With African Nature And Wildlife
Title: N/A

reviewText: From Jamie Uys, the director who gave us "The Gods must be Crazy 1 and 2" comes this very differently made yet interesting documentary. Only "Walt Disney's Wild Life Adventures" comes close. The enduring beauty of the lives of the animals, their natural habitats and the beauty of African nature all come together in this documentary that shares several scenes (particularly about the Kalahari bushmen) with "The Gods must be crazy" films.Considering documentaries made of animals during that era "King Elephant", "Ape and Super Ape" Jamie Uys made sure the documentary was entertaining and that is the highlight of the movie. However watching the DVD many years later a lot of errors can be spotted. The inebriated apes scene after consumption of the fruit was completed fabricated. The scene where the bushman traps the monkey using the old fist-in-the-bottle trick was animated and literally took away the joy of the real thing. Even the sidewinder scaring off the elephant in the desert, and a drop of dew acting as a lens for the sunlight to burn of a nest seemed phony (editing tricks) though such happenings are possible. But otherwise several other beautiful scenes make this a great DVD to watch with your kids and for first-timers.When it was released in Chennai decades ago it was titled "Beautiful People" and it had a run like any of the blockbusters of that time did.
summary: Beautiful indeed, a different kind of a documentary
Title: N/A

reviewText: My husband, four-year old son, and I watched this film for the first time last night and were all riveted by it. This is the first nature/animal film I have ever viewed that did not have bits I had to hide my little boys eyes from (nature in the raw can be very rough for a small child to understand), but which did convey accurately the dangers that exist for animals from larger predators, as well as from extreme weather (floods, drought, and a bit of fire as well). Further, the narration was informative and entertaining while not once talking down to my son (or us for that matter), which is exceedingly rare in my experience; other animal films for children resort to turning the animals into silly caricatures of themselves, or giving them irritating voices. Not so with this film. This images captured were stunning and were presented in such a clever, thoughtful way. Much of the music that accompanied it was from Tchaikovsky's "The Nut Cracker", which was a lovely touch.Several other reviewers took exception to what they felt was the degradation of animals to comical characters, which I don't feel is accurate. Nature is full of quirky, extraordinary animals that exhibit all sorts of clever behavioral traits to attract mates, protect their young, gain and protect territory, etc. Some examples in this film are the mother duck's behavior to protect her ducklings, the honey badger's relationship to the bird he partners with to secure honey and the young lion whose job it was to protect a watering-hole while the rest of the pride relaxed in the shade. Those are just a few examples of fascinating (and oft little known) relationships and behaviors that exist in nature and are quite comical to watch from the human perspective. It should be pointed out that the behaviors of humans in the film (primarily while hunting) were humorous as well, though I certainly didn't find it offensive or degrading. Creating a balance between masterful, informative, respectful story-telling in an entertaining enough way to hold the attention of small children and adults alike is difficult at best. In my experience this film does a masterful job of balancing all those elements to create a truly unusual and genuine film that is both educational and a pleasure to watch. At no point did I feel that animals were being mocked. Rather, I thought their innovativeness and uniqueness was celebrated at every turn.Like several other reviewers I too am a fan of National Geographic documentaries. It's hard to imagine anyone not loving their lush photography and the far-flung places their films depict. However, that level of documentary is not suited to my four-year old; the kind of carnage that predators unleash on one another in those films is entirely normal and natural, but it is far too upsetting and confusing for a small child. That's one of the many reasons that I am so delighted to have discovered Animals are Beautiful People.I recommend this film very, very highly both for children and adults. I learned so much watching it and had a wonderful time doing so. We three were all able to laugh out loud more than once (when was the last time you were able to say that after watching an informative nature film), and to have lively discussions about what we were seeing throughout the film. Really, do try this movie - you won't regret it.
summary: Brilliant, fascinating, entertaining, and NOT just for kids!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This "Documentary" was produced by the same guy who went on to do "The Gods Must be Crazy".It is very funny in parts, but for parents who don't want their kids seeing baby birds dying by the hundreds, don't watch the last 15 minutes (I don't mind my kids seeing this, but I thought I'd throw in that caveat)Like an earlier reviewer, I too thought that nest fire looked set up.  There was just no reason for the camera to be focusing on that one drop that happened to start the fire.Also, that same reviewer pointed out the "drunk scene" was man made, so I checked out the site he mentioned (wildwatch.com), and if you search around the plant section (some plant that start with an m, sorry I forget which).Here is the relavent text:"Due to its well-known alcoholic capacities, rumours abound as to the Marula's intoxicating effects on wild animals. While elephants and baboons both relish the fruit, the former would need to consume prodigious amounts of already fermenting fruit for it to have even the mildest impact, and since these huge animals drink up to 160 litres of water a day, there would anyway be a major diluting effect. Interestingly, examination of fresh elephant dung show that less than ten percent of Marula fruits are actually 'processed' in any way - most fruit passes through the digestive tract intact.Observations on baboons suggest that they prefer fresh Marula fruit and because the pulp is digested and the seeds passed within a 24-hour period, fermentation is impossible. The infamous scene in a popular movie from the 1970s - Jamie Uys' 'Beautiful People', which depicted a troop of obviously drunken baboons in and under a Marula tree, was clearly man-induced and would today be outlawed in terms of animal cruelty."When I first saw this video, (...)  Watching it with the knowledge that it was set up, made it seem rather cruel.Despite this, I still found this movie very entertaining on the whole.
summary: Some staged scenes, but very entertaining
